Oh!  where shall I find the retreat,</br>Which peace for its mansion has chose?</br>Oh!  when shall I see the bless'd seat,</br>Or meet with a cure for my woes?
Since Phillis, the pride of the plain,</br>To Damon inconstant doth prove,</br>His vows she doth treat with disdain,</br>Nor longer will listen to love.
Then whither, Oh where must I fly!</br>Can solitude health re-instate?</br>Can it give to my bosom that joy,</br>I was robb'd of by Phillis and fate?
Can society comfort impart,</br>Or the town's busy tumults delight?</br>Since the nymph that's possess'd of my heart,</br>With frowns doth my passion requite?
No, — all comfort is fled from my mind,</br>Nor the town's busy mirth can relieve;</br>Nor can I from solitude find,</br>That ease which my Phillis could give.
When Damon was blest in your love,</br>How oft have I know you resolve,</br>That constant you ever would prove;</br>'Till death should our passion dissolve.
Yet health's crimson blush doth remain,</br>Your cheeks with the tincture doth glow,</br>And yet you prove fair to the swain,</br>No longer your smiles you bestow.
When seated beside yon clear stream,</br>With your face on my bosom reclin'd;</br>Whilst love was our fav'rite theme,</br>What harmony dwelt in my mind!
If I doubted your truth you would chide,</br>And say, that ere faithless you'd prove,</br>The current would cease then to glide,</br>Nor stream, when you ceased to love.
Still the water does lucidly flow</br>Does your love still as constant remain?</br>Ah Phillis!  It murmurs, ah, no!</br>Echo murmurs it back from the plain.
My crook I have broke, and my reed</br>No more in the concert doth play,</br>My flocks too disorderly feed,</br>And far from my Phillis's stray.
"My Phillis's!" hush'd be the voice,</br>Now her's do with Strephon's resort,</br>For Strephon is Phillis's choice,</br>And Damon is Phillis's sport.
Nor the vale, nor the groves winding shade,</br>Nor the bow'r which my hands did compose,</br>Tho' in spring's verdant mantle array'd,</br>Can charm my fond soul to repose.
When the swains and the nymphs, ever gay,</br>Join hands, and the dance does go round,</br>From the throng I dejectedly stray,</br>And shrink from their pipes jocund sound!
Ye warblers, no longer you please,</br>No more can your music delight;</br>From my bosom is banish'd all ease,</br>Life's lamp is extinguished quite.
Oh Phillis!  when I am no more,</br>Will reflection not torment thy breast?</br>Will death not thy pity restore,</br>Nor conscience debar thee from rest?
Now Strephon with Phillida doth rove,</br>For Strephon poor Damon was scorn'd;</br>She returns his professions of love,</br>Nor thinks of poor Damon entomb'd.
But Strephon beware of the maid,</br>Let not passion thy reason beguile,</br>Think, Oh think, on poor Damon betray'd!</br>There's perjury lurks in each smile.
May thy days, gentle swain ever roll,</br>On a smooth level passage of life;</br>May ne'er fate thy best wishes controul,</br>And Phillis bless thee as a wife.
But, Phillis, remember — the swain,</br>Who when living thy footsteps did tread,</br>Will attend on thy paths still again,</br>And haunt thy repose when I'm dead.</br>
